title: Song Notebooks, 1893-1959 [b005] [f001] [001_044]
description: George Avery Robinson (1878-1965) was born in Louisville, Kentucky. After attending Harvard and working as a business manager, Robinson served in France during the First World War. He moved to England in 1920 to study music composition and work as treasurer for the Royal Philharmonic Society. He returned to the United States in 1931 where he continued to compose and arrange music, work with numerous popular musicians such as Roland Hayes and Paul Robeson, and work with his wife's perfume company, Mary Chess, Inc. This collection contains manuscripts of his musical works, as well as correspondence, photographs, and other records related to Robinson's professional pursuits and family life.|Contains notebooks with fragments and draft copies of music written, transcribed, arranged, or collected by Avery Robinson, Carley Robinson, and Mildred J. Hill. These notebooks document work these musicians conducted in writing down and collecting music and lyrics from Black communities in Kentucky and throughout the South, as well as their own compositions, and lessons taken or given professionally. Of particular importance in this series are two notebooks of "Negro Hymns" collected by Mildred J. Hill in Kentucky in the late 1890s.|Negro Hymns from Mildred J. Hill, Jubilee songs
